content.answer_title: Supreme Court of India's Right to Privacy Jurisprudence on Aadhaar & Data Protection (2017–2025)
content.final_answer: In *Puttaswamy v. Union of India* (2017), the SC recognized privacy as a fundamental right (Article 21). The *2018 Aadhaar verdict* upheld constitutionality but limited biometric collection to welfare, struck s.7’s private-sector linkage, and mandated data protection. The DPDP Act (2023) codifies these limits, aligning with Puttaswamy’s proportionality and consent principles. 2023–2025 rulings (e.g., *M.V. Rajareddy*) reaffirmed biometric data protection under DPDP and DPA oversight. All Aadhaar processing requires strict necessity, and consent, per UIDAI’s encryption standards (2023 circular). content.answer_title: India's 2025 Data Privacy & Digital Surveillance Updates
content.final_answer: In 2025, India advanced its Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023 with Draft Rules (Jan 3, Feb 22, Jun 5) detailing consent, DPIA, breach protocols, and child/disabled safeguards. MeitY (Jan 3) pushed rapid implementation, public consultations, and toolkits. Parliament (Jul 28) flagged MeitY’s Rs 1,574 crore underutilisation and DPDP delays, demanding accountability. Media bodies (Aug 23) submitted 35 FAQs on press exemptions, urging public-interest guidance. DPDP Rules introduced a 15-90-day third-party effective period, GDPR-aligned cross-border norms, and strict penalties (up to ₹2 crore). No major 2025 digital surveillance amendments yet, but DPDP enforcement prioritises federal-regulator (DPBI) oversight.
